prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Band 4 (2 millimeter) is the longest wavelength where the high dust concentration can still be azimuthally resolved in the highest resolution of the C36-8 configuration. The millimeter flux is well-known from previous observations and we require a S/N of at least 50 to measure the azimuthal extent.

We set the basebands for large continuum coverage, with three basebands at line mode broadband (1875 MHz bandwidth per band) for higher continuum sensitivity and the 4th baseband centered at the DCO+ 2-1 line at 0.3 km/s resolution for better line sensitivity on this particular line which could be serendipitously detected. There is a possibility of other serendipitous line detections with 2.5 km/s resolution. We have set the correlator to set the data rate below 12 Mb/s.

The angular scale of 0.05" is required to measure the azimuthal and radial extent of the dust continuum, which is expected to be a few beams wide. Based on our predictions, no large scale dust emission will be resolved out.

We have set the correlator such that the data rate stays below 12 Mb/s, but we require high sensitivity on the lines. For the best line sensitivity, the basebands containing CO lines are set to FDM mode with 0.1 km/s resolution. In addition to the CO isotopologues we target several other diagnostic lines for serendipitous detection at lower spectral resolution to increase the continuum sensitivity. These additional lines have been chosen based on the frequency of the CO line and their possible detection.

The angular resolution is chosen to be able to resolve the 25 AU gas cavity in IRS 48 and to measure the depth accurately, as explained in the text and Figure 2. Although some emission in the outer disk may be resolved out, the main goal of this setting is to constrain the inner disk. The gas structure in the outer disk is constrained by previous ALMA observations at lower spatial resolution.

The sensitivity is based on the predictions of our gas model for IRS 48 for the CO lines, based on previous observations at lower spatial resolution. We find a rms level of 1.7 mJy/beam per 1 km/s channel for 50 minutes on source integration. Since the main goal of these observations is to constrain the density drop within 25 AU, our S/N demands are based on this value (see also Figure 2). Our model calculations for 12CO 2-1 reach a maximum of 0.1 Jy/beam inside the 25 AU gas hole for the highest value of deltagas of 1E-1, and less than 0.006 Jy/beam for a deltagas of 1E-4. Thus a S/N of ~60 is reached for the highest deltagas, down to a non-detection for deltagas=1E-4.

We have set the correlator such that the data rate stays below 12 Mb/s, but we require high sensitivity on the lines. For the best line sensitivity, the basebands containing CO lines are set to FDM mode with 0.1 km/s resolution. In addition to the CO isotopologues we target several other diagnostic lines for serendipitous detection at lower spectral resolution to increase the continuum sensitivity. These additional lines have been chosen based on the frequency of the CO line and their possible detection.

The angular resolution is chosen to be able to resolve the 7 AU gas cavity in SR 21 and to measure the depth accurately, as explained in the text and Figure 2. The emission in the outer disk will be resolved out in both lines and continuum, but the main goal of this setting is to constrain the inner disk. The gas structure in the outer disk is constrained by previous ALMA observations at lower spatial resolution.

The sensitivity is based on the predictions of our gas model for SR21 for the CO lines, based on previous observations at lower spatial resolution. We find a rms level of 2.8 mJy/beam per 1 km/s channel for 20 minutes on source integration. Since the main goal of these observations is to constrain the density drop within 7 AU, our S/N demands are based on this value (see also Figure 2). Our model calculations for 12CO 2-1 reach a maximum of 0.1 Jy/beam inside the 7 AU gas hole for the highest value of deltagas of 1E-2, 0.02 for deltagas=1E-5, and 0.003 Jy/beam for a deltagas of 1E-6. Thus a S/N of ~60 is reached for the highest deltagas, down to a non-detection inside 7 AU for deltagas=1E-6.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Planets are formed in disks of gas and dust around young stars, but their formation and properties at this early stage are unclear. We have observed density drops (signature of embedded planets) in the gas of several transition disks, where the gas gap is smaller than the dust gap. The millimeter dust is gathered in a so-called dust trap at the outer edge of the gas gap, either as ring or azimuthal asymmetry. For Oph IRS 48 such a gas gap is seen, but due to limited spatial resolution the depth can not be well determined. For SR 21 a gas gap is known from rovibrational CO lines, but so far unresolved in ALMA observations. We propose deeper observations of these fascinating disks, targeting the CO 2-1 isotopologues at 0.1" and 0.05" resolution to measure the depth of the gas gaps. The measurements will give us direct insight in potential embedded planets and will tell us more about their formation process and feedback on the disk. As a secondary goal we will measure the wavelength-dependent azimuthal extent of the Oph IRS 48 dust trap and derive the trapping efficiency through combined observations of Band 4 and 6 data in combination with previously obtained Band 9 continuum.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: This proposal is a partial resubmission of the accepted proposal 2013.1.00100.S (PI van der Marel). Only one SG of that proposal has been observed so far. If the remaining part of the program will be observed before the start of Cycle 3, SG2 of this proposal can be omitted and the total time is only 1.5 hours.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Center for Astronomy, Heidelberg, University of
Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory, Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics
Kavli Institute for Astronomy and Astrophysics, Peking University
